awd_titl_txt: CAREER: Data-Driven User Interface Designs for Culturally Diverse Groups
awd_abstract_narration:
This research will systematically investigate how to make information technology more accessible to users from varied cultural backgrounds. Research shows that user interfaces designed for undifferentiated markets are less usable, less intuitive, and less appealing than are locally designed interfaces, making users less efficient and less satisfied. The results will inform novel user interface design guidelines and help build both models and tools for interface designers and end users that support the automated adaption of web interfaces to specific cultural groups. Guidelines and tools to be produced in this project will assist businesses in making decisions about, reducing costs associated with, and increasing total revenue and net income derived from preparing products for international markets.  Educational goals of this project are to (1) involve high school and undergraduate students from varied cultural and demographic backgrounds in this research, (2) create and disseminate open-source educational materials that immediately affect designers' understanding and creation of inclusive website designs, and (3) use citizen scientists to participate in and promote research results to the public.
 
To foster information inclusiveness, this research aims to translate seminal lab-based studies on visual perception into large-scale online experiments that will be administered globally on our experiment platform, LabintheWild. The research will systematically investigate the influence of human diversity on visual perception and on user interface design. Traditional academic studies conducted with small, locally recruited convenience samples are not always generalizable given their skew toward unrepresentative test subjects. This research will vastly extend conventional study populations using a proven crowdsourced experiment platform and thereby more generalizably contribute to the knowledge domains of visual perception, cultural psychology, human-computer interaction, and adaptive user interfaces by providing: (1) scientific findings on human perception that compare people from at least 30 countries and varied demographic backgrounds (2) best practice, data-driven user interface design guidelines for these groups, (3) predictive models and tools that support the automated adaption of web interfaces to varied user backgrounds, and (4) evaluations of whether these tools successfully improve work efficiency and user satisfaction.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Computer and Information Science and Engineering

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: REU SUPP-Res Exp for Ugrd Supp

por.por_cntn:
This project explored how user interfaces should be designed to be more inclusive of people from various cultural backgrounds. The research team conducted several large-scale online experiments to investigate cultural differences in human perception, preferences, and behaviors when interacting with graphical user interfaces. Analyzing participant data from more than 200  countries gathered through the team’s virtual lab, the LabintheWild, the research showed that people indeed vary in how they perceive and interact with user interfaces and related these differences to cultural characteristics. For example, while some cultures tend to more holistically reason about information, others use a more analytic reasoning style. This can translate into a preference for different levels of visual complexity and also influence how people approach finding information on user interfaces. Based on these findings, the research team developed guidelines and tools for adapting graphical user interfaces to culture, showing that adapted user interfaces improve user satisfaction, work efficiency, and conversion rates. 


The findings have been integrated into the learning materials for computer science students at the University of Washington and many other universities, thus supporting the development of more inclusive technology by the next generation of designers and developers. Overall, the work raises awareness that there is no silver bullet to user interface design that equally fits all because design decisions are inherently cultural. By contributing new insights into how user interface designs can be suitable for people from some countries while being biased against others, this work has revealed how seemingly mundane design decisions can yield incredible power. In the future, the results of this work can be used to lower access barriers that many people currently encounter if the technology’s underlying cultural values are misaligned with their own. 


Last Modified: 08/14/2023
Modified by: Katharina Reinecke
